DIV1.P: THE BOX-LOBBY CHALLENGE, A COMEDY.
As performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL, HAY-MARKET.
WRITTEN BY RICHARD CUMBERLAND, Esq.
NOS HAEC NOVIMUS ESSE NIHIL.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR J. DEBRETT, OPPOSITE BURLINGTON.
HOUSE, PICCADILLY.
[PRICE Is. 6d.]

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by the Hon. FRANCIS NORTH.
DIV1.L: AS some fond father, who a bantling rears,
Feels nought but pleasure in his tender years;
His tricks at school, and all the pranks he plays,
E'en the boy's foibles then excite his praise.
A little spirit well becomes a youth;
Jack, though unlucky, always speaks the truth.
But when arriv'd at a maturer age,
He launches Jackey upon life's great stage:
With joy elate, with anxious fears deprest,
What hopes and horrors fill a parent's breast!
E'er yet he dares to cast the dangerous die,
And shew his darling to the public eye,
The hopes of all his future joy he sends,
To visit some, he knows to be his friends:
Surly exclaims, eat up with gout and spleen,
The stripling's well enough, but much too lean;
He'll be shortliv'd, he has his mother's cough,
A galloping consumption took her off.
Is this Sir Jacob's son? Old Toothless cries,
The boy is of a most alarming size:
Such o'ergrown monsters never can be strong;
Don't tell his father, but he can't live long.
So when the bard at first prepares his play,
His heart beats high, and all his prospects gay:
'Tis done, 'tis done, the enraptured poet cries,
The labour's over, I shall grasp the prize;
Snarler, upon whose word I can depend;
Snarler, shall see it, he's indeed a friend.
How do ou like my piece?—good critic say?
Nay do not flatter; don't you like the play?
Why yes, Sir,—eh—the thing is well enough;
Is it not good? Humph, yes—what cursed stuff!
I think, my friend, the play-house will be cramm'd!
I think so too—and think your play 'll be damn'd.
At length the night, the aweful night ensues,
Fatal to many an offspring of the muse:
The father bids his fancy's child appear,
And hopes to meet no friendly snarler here;
Moral his boy, if entertaining too,
His fortune's fairly made when judg'd by you.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: SCENE—London.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A Back Room to a Printer's Office, CROTCHET with a Table before him in his Chair reading. THEO∣DOSIA enters from the Side.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: NOBODY in the office? Nobody to tend the trade? Mr. Crotchet, what are you about?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Reading.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Is that a printer's business?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: No, but what can I do with my authors? No one else reads them, so I must.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Get a fresh set, and clear away your old hack∣nies; they are crippled, founder'd, work'd off their legs—

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: And starv'd. Has Fulsome call'd with his de∣dication?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Must the press stand still till that fellow's mud deposits? What did Slang want in the office?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Credit for a quire of foolscap.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: You didn't give it him?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Who had been the fool then? Where's our Jacky?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Up all night, abed all morning; a whelp, a blockhead as he is. I thought to have made a great man of him, and educated him accordingly. I set him out in the world as printer's devil to one of the first presses in the capital.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: And a pretty devil he has been ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: I then gave him a spell with our neighbour the rag-merchant, at next door.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: What could he learn there?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: What could he learn? the elements of his trade, the embryo of all good writing before it goes to the paper∣mill. He might have studied letters at the foundery itself, and the most valuable part of the chief libraries in the kingdom at the bookbinders: Nobody can say I baulk'd Jack in his education.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Why didn't you give him some grammar-school learning?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: What good had that done him? Learning only cramps the genius, and grammar does but cripple the stile: Give me an author of a free clear mind. Why isn't he up in his cock-loft now with pen an ink? There's fresh air that would help his fancy. There he might court the muses and the graces.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Instead of which he courts them in the streets to the music of the watchman's rattle.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: It seems then that he makes some noise in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: By the way, husband, what is this new work of Fulsome's which you are printing?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: A Treatise on Education.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Has that fellow any wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: He has cunning, which is cousin-german to it. Fulsome was usher to a country school, he married the femme de chambre of a rich dowager, who took him into her family, and made him bear-leader to her booby son; he danc'd him a tour thro' Europe, and publish'd it in two quarto volumes at his return, pirated from the jour∣nals of other travellers, and stuffed with drawings of tem∣ples, bridges, aqueducts and amphitheatres, most of which he had never seen, and none of which he had ever examin'd: The book sold, and with the profits of that and a small pen∣sion Fulsome makes a shift to live.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Enough! I see him entering the office.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: I kiss your hands, worthy Mr. Crotchet; I pray you lay me at the feet of your amiable spouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Compliments apart, let us to business.—Where's your Dedication of the Treatise?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: In the hands of the Dedicatee, Mrs. or Miss Diana Grampus, I protest I know not by which title to address her, for she is a virgin in the bloom of half an hundred; vain, rich, pedantic, and not a little partial to your hum∣ble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: But what is this to our business?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Patience, padrone mio! it is to your business: in the first place you must think a Dedication of this sort, where all the virtues, not to be found in her character, are to be hammer'd out of my brain, is no perfunctory job: in the next I must tell you, that I have an interest in Di Grampus, on which I mean to found a project for making the fortune of a friend of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Meaning yourself, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: My heroine has a nephew, the only son of Sir Toby Grampus, now coming to town for the purpose of putting this uneducated cub under her protection: I have recommended the tour of Italy, and the proposal takes.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: So you're going to lead another bear round the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Not so, my travels are finished, and I have made over my interest to your son John.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: My son! my son Jack a travelling tutor!

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: And why not, Mr. Crotchet?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Because I think his travels point to a quarter where few young gentlemen go for education.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Don't be discouraged; I hold it for an axiom, that every man is sit for every thing he can get. John is giddy to be sure, but with a few of my instructions he will pas: He does not want address.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Call it impudence, and you are right.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P:
For shame, husband; he has no more impudence
than a man of fashion should have. I wish indeed he had the languages.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Why that, perhaps, that wou'd be well if he had; but I hope it will be got over—a foreign lacquey must sup∣ply that defect: If he is ignorant of the living languages we must puff him the more for his knowledge of the dead ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Dead ones indeed, and dead they will remain for ever, if they wait for his bringing them to life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Why, surely he had an university education.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: You are laughing at me, methinks; you know well enough what education he has had.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: True, true, as you say, my zeal there went a lit∣tle too far, for I told Mrs. Diana he was a scholar of the first class at Cambridge, carried all the prizes, all the me∣dals; it was an error on the right side, for she believes it, and it is not our business to undeceive her: We must stand by what we have said. But where is he all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Where he always is till noon; fast asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Let him tke his nap out. Send him to me as soon as he is drest: let him come to my lodgings; I'll give him his cue and carry him to Di Grampus, where I warrant you we will clinch the business. Good morning to you! I shall expect him about noon.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: The fellow's mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: You are, methinks, to stand in the way of your son's preferment.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Jack Crotchet a travelling tutor! Was there ever such a chimera?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Many such, and successful ones. Our Jack has a good deal of ready wit, knows the world, has no false modesty, and with good cloaths on his back is a personable fellow: Who is more likely to make his fortune among ladies of a certain cast?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Egad, Theodosia, thou hast struck the only flint that has any fire in it. I begin to think better of the project than I did. Call him up, however; call him up: We can soon rig him out from the warehouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Why, Jacky; Jacky, I say—Jacky Crotchet!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: What's the matter with you? here am I, set me a chair, mother! (yawns and stretches, begins to tye up his garters, and button his cloaths,) What a bawling you make! Cats and creaking hinges cannot jar my nerves more in∣sufferably than your Jackey, Jackey! vulgar, puerile, gross—leave off that familiarity.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Where have you been, sirrah, to be thus be∣devil'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Kept it up—prime spirits—best of company—

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: What a figure you have made of yourself! why your coat-lappet is all over dirt.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Yes, the gentleman's shoes were not over-clean that made free with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: You have been kickt, have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Box-lobby quarrel, nothing more, gave him my card—never put up with an affront, damme.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: What do you mean by your card?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Sword and Pistol.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch,
SP.P: Zooks! we shall have a duel in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: No, no, no, you wont; there'll be no duel, un∣less the gentleman, whose name is on the ticket, chuses to fight—always make free with a friend on those occasions.—Borrow'd this frock-suit—found the owner's ticket in the waistcoat pocket—carried it off with spirit—left the house with a high hand—foot slipt, tumbled over a fruit-woman—sav'd half-price, and pocketed three oranges in the scramble.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: You'll scramble to the gallows.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: You think so—differ from you, much doubt if I shall reach the pillory, and that will be a falling-off in the family; one step lower in the scale than my predecessor.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Rascal, who told you that I have been in the pillory?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: A long-ear'd goddess, gossip Fame, says you had so many eggs for breakfast, you've never had a sto∣mach for an omlet since.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Get out of my presence, or I'll send this vo∣lume at your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Better let that alone; you have had enough of pelting, methinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Fie upon you, Jackey, treat your father with more respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: A miscreant, a reprobate, to talk to me in such a stile—I give him up; I'll have nothing more to say to him; I cou'd have made the fellow's fortune for him, but I would not step across the gutter to save him from a gibbet.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: There, there! now you've ruin'd all. Such an offer, such a lucky hit—do but hear reason, and I'll stand your friend still.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Well, well, I will hear reason—but he was set in the Pillory, wasn't he?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Prythee, what is that to the purpose? Here has been Mr. Fulsome here, who has recommended you to Mrs. Diana Grampus to travel with her nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Diana Grampus! what sort of a fish is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: A fish do you call her? she's as rich as a jewess, and her nephew is son and heir to Sir Toby Grampus, a man of great estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: How old is Diana?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: About fifty.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: An antiquated goddess of fifty: Damme, I'll make up to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: How you rattle! mind your own interest, and make up to dame fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: No, I'll attack Diana of Ephesus, and set fire to her temple;—well, but after all, mother, he was in the pillory; confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Hold your tongue about the pillory, and get some decent clothes on your back; I'll provide them for you. Come, set about dressing yourself, there's no time to be lost. You must call upon Fulsome at his lodgings, and he will carry you to the lady patroness.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Well, well, get me something for my breakfast in the first place: Send for a fellow to pinch these hang∣dogs into buckle, get me a fashionable suit, and I will sally forth to the chace of Diana: Rat me if I think any old girl of fifty can withstand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P:
Now, Jack, now is your time; if you will but mind your hits and follow the instructions Mr. Fulsome shall give you: Dont be rhodomontading in your idle way to
expose yourself to the lady, who will be sure to find you out. Put on a grave appearance before her, and leave the rest to your friend: All you have for it is to look wise and keep silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Say no more, say no more; get my breakfast, set my things to dress, and I'll be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Well then, I'll about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Hold! a word with you; before I stir a foot from this place tell me in plain truth whether the old boy was set in the pillory, aye or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Obstinate, perverse!—I tell you then he was—now be content,

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: That's enough—he was in the pillory. Oh! that I had been in the way to have seen him! I am glad I know the truth: I have a fine pull upon him: he has'nt heard the last of it I can tell him.—Oho! Lindamira—

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: So, rattlebrain, what's the news with you? From what watch-house, night-stll, or cyder-cellar have you redeem'd that dirty dissipated person of your's to put to shame the modest eye of day.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: The modest eye of day! From what conceit∣ed, canting, coxcombly, drab-compos'd novel have you filch'd that silly phrase?

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: I filch from none; my phrases are original, my scenes are Nature's self, my stile Pactolus rolling over golden sands. Here is my manuscript; a novel, pictures∣que, descriptive.—Salvator, Claude, Poussin, Vernet, may blush to see themselves out done: My sun, moon, stars; my mountains, hills, vales, rivers, lakes; my woods, heaths rocks and ruins, are not dawbings upon canvas, but all embroidered upon cloth of gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I would not give you one sarthing for the sum total of them; I abominate descriptions. Have you nature, humour, wit, character? Is your hero a man or a mon∣ster? Your heroine a woman or an angel? Do your peo∣ple make love, Lindy, as you and I have made it, accord∣ing to the rules of flesh and blood; or as Sylphs and Syl∣phines do out of aether and gas.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Read and reform:

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Why should I do that which my author does not? but come, since you are so zealous for my reforma∣tion, bring your novel with you up stairs, and you shall read it to me whilst I dress,

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Tis to the toilet of the ladies, not of the men, my compositions are address'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Well, and I will carry it to the toilette of the ladies: let me have a sample of it, and I'll lay you into old Di Grampus for a dedication.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Diana Grampus! the very lady I am going to, the first patroness to a dedication in all England. How came you to know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Know her, child! I'm going to be married to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Oh you monster! you villain! have you for∣got your vows, your promises to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: What's a coming now? Gentle novelist, ruffle not the sweet serenity of your soul! Imitate your own heroine:—

Q.L: Soft as the dew-drop on the blushing rose,
The pearly tear shall trickle down your nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: My nose! you fool, my cheek you should have said.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Yes, but cheek would not rhime to rose—so come along, for I have no time to lose.
SP.STAGE: A Room in an Hotel. A Waiter passes over the Stage! JOE follows, carrying his Master's cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Harkye, you boy! skip-jack! tapster!

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: What do you want, Clodpole? is that your way of speaking to a waiter? I fancy you have been more accustomed to alehouses than hotels.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Oho! you call your house an hotel, and yourself a waiter—very well! then pray Mr. Waiter of an hotel, send me hither one of your barbers to comb out Sir Toby Grampus's perriwig.—Do you understand that?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: I'll send you a hair-dresser, we don't call 'em barbers, unless we mean to aftront 'em. Where the plague have you liv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: So, o here's a new language to learn; a man's mother-tongue I perceive is of no use in this place.
Your humble servant, Sir! pray what am I to call you?

SP.SPEAKER: Hair-dresser.
SP.P: Did'nt you send for a hair dresser? where is the gentleman that wants to be dress'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: There; there he is, upon that block.

SP.SPEAKER: Hair-dresser.
SP.P: This! this! who does this belong to?

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: To my master. Whilst I am brushing his coat, you will amuse yourself with combing out his perriwig.

SP.SPEAKER: Hair-dresser.
SP.P: Dam'mee! if I woud'nt as soon comb out the tower lyons, as this rum gig of a caxen.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Rum gig of a caxen! what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Hair dresser.
SP.P: Why 'tis a second edition of Sir Cloudesly Shovel in the tombs. Your master will look for all the world like King Charles in the oak with his bush at his back, brother Brush.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Brother Brush! that's not my name; my name is Joe Thresher; I have lived by that name and none other in Sir Toby Grampus's service these thirty years come next Lammas.

SP.SPEAKER: Hair-dresser.
SP.P: Very right, very right! the thresher you know naturally follows the whale; and which now is of the longest standing in the family, you, or that damn'd old quiz of a coat you are dusting?

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Damn'd old quiz of a coat! what a graceless re∣probate you are! Damme, how you barbers swear! where do you expect to go?

SP.SPEAKER: Hair-dresser.
SP.P: Half the town over before night, then to my girl and my bottle. As for your wig, comb it those that like, I'll not touch a bristle of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Come in, Master Bobby, come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Ah, Joey, my hearty fellow; where's old dad? not bolted yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: No, no, but I look for him every moment: Pri∣the, Squire, do you mean to go in that trim to Madam Diana's? They say she's main proud, and has a world of fine quality folks at her house; she'll turn up her nose at you in that bumpkin jacket.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: If she don't like the bumpkin as he is, she may leave him; dost think I'll cut my jacket to her cloth? not I; I'll not wear a tail where my head grows for her or any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: But what will you say when the pretty Misses come to jeer and flout, and call you country putt and the like? You'll be spruc'd and powder'd out I warrant me with the best of 'em before many days are over your head. I do hear it said, Squire, (but that's between you and me) that Madam Di means to send you out upon a progress into fo∣reign parts beyond seas.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: With all my heart, I love to be moving; all places are alike to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Why that's honest; to be sure 'tis a fine thing to travel from place to place, and see strange sights, and live amongst wild men and wild beasts, lions and tygers and mountain cats, as some gentlemen tell us of.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: See 'em Joe! by the living I'll see 'em and eat 'em too.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Do, master Bobby; if you love me, do eat a lion.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I will, I'll eat him raw, and hash the snout of an elephant in a rhinoceros's shell.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Oh rare!

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Why I tell you I have been with the rhinoce∣ros this very morning, on purpose to make acquaintance with him before we met in his own country. A civil obliging gentleman, show'd me the way, but in his hurry I suspect he mistook my pocket for his own, for I've left my purse, watch, and handkerchief behind me; nothing remains in my pocket but three golden pippins, which I suppose were not to his liking.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir TOBY GRAMPUS in his Night Gown and Cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What's a clock, Joe?

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Close upon noon—your honor never lies so long in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Nor sleep so little;—such a bawling crew of watchmen; they may be well call'd guardians of the night, for they take care nobody shall fall asleep in it—but come, we must bustle; sister Di will be expecting us—Ah Bob! I did not see thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Honor'd father, I beg your blessing,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Blss you, bless you, my boy, and make you a good man, and an honour to your family!—Help me on with my coat, Joe you must stick tight to it now, Bob, and buckle to your business, and attend to your masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Oh yes, father, you know I had made some progress before I left home; I cou'd compass a tune or two upon the French horn, and handle the quarter-staff pretty smartly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Pooh, pooh, mun, you must think of other matters than french-horns and quarter-staffs—give me my wig.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Why, is'nt Grandfather painted with a French horn across his shoulder in the hunting parlour at home? and who was so famous at the quarter-staff as uncle Ro∣bert? His name is up I'm sure in Monmouthshire, and how should I be an honour to my family if I dont keep up to the spirit of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Yes, yes, but times are alter'd, Bob, times are alter'd—Why, Sirrah, you have not comb'd this wig out of buckle.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Please your honour, here was a prig of a barber came to dress it, who swore, damn him, he'd as soon comb the lions in the Tower: he woudn't touch a bristle of it—never heard such a reprobate in my days.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P:
Oh, that I had the knave in Monmouthshire, I'd make him sing another tune!—But what was I saying to you, Bob? Aye, this it was—Times are not as they were, my lad; the good days are over; plain folks are not
thought of, and landed gentlemen are little valued but for rearing stock and sowing turnips; fine folks now carry no horns across their shoulders, they wear them in other places. A country gentlemen of a good estate in your grandfather's time, and a baronet, as he was, wou'dn't have troubled his head with Greek and Latin, and laws and politics, farther than opposing the minister right or wrong, he car'd not which; for why? because he knew it was for the good of his country.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Very true, father, that comes of course.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: But now, do you see, they will have a reason for every thing, aye, and oftentimes so many reasons for the same thing, that the plain truth is puzzled by their prove∣ing it. In old times every body sate silent in company with their superiors, nobody spoke till they were spoken to; no tongue was heard at the table but the master's of it; now they are all talkers and no hearers, such a gabble and a din; every priggish puppy gives his puppily opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Very true, father, and so long-winded, that it sets me a yawning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: This being the case, Bob, it's high time for the old families to look about 'em, a true Grampus must not let the small fry get over his head; therefore, you see, that you may be able to keep pace with the world as it goes, and not to be thrown out of the talk, or made to take eve∣ry thing upon trust that people choose to talk about, but see with your own eyes and judge for yourself, I propose, by your aunt's advice, to send you forth upon your travels; and as you have shewn such a talent for music, by your per∣formances on the horn, you shall start for Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: And what shall I see there, father?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: See! why you'll see the Pope of Rome, and the twelve Caesars, and the naked Venus, and Saint Peter's church, and the burning mountains, and all those sort of things.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Oh, good your honour, let master Bobby go see the crocodiles, and the pyramids, and the rhinocerosses, all alive in their own country.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Yes, pray do; I may see them at a cheaper rate there than I can here, and I have a mighty liking for wild beasts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P:
Boy, thou shalt see every thing, and that you
may'st do nothing at second hand and by halves, I will have thee go to the very head of the Nile, and drink of the spring that waters the whole realm of Pharoah.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Enough said, father. I shan't seek to go any fur∣ther, especially if I meet with no better entertainment; I shall then be well content to come back into Monmouth∣shire, where I can drink out of a cellar, which for my part I prefer to all the springs in the creation.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: All the world to nothing: There you are right, Master Bobby.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Let me only have a good companion to drink with me by the way, and not one of your bushy-wig'd bear-leaders, with a four temper and a solemn face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Never fear that, lad; thou shalt have no pe∣dagogue nor parson, to travel with his school books in his pocket, and rummage old walls for inscriptions, and hunt after tombs. What is it to thee, who never read a line of Virgil, where he lies buried? Thy companion shall be a man of fashion, prudent but chearful, cautious yet good-humour'd, moral but not austere; one that has read men more than books, and knows the world, not by the map and the globe, but by observation and experience. Such an one I hope to find of sister Di's providing, so let us lose no time but set forward. Joe tell the people to call us a coach.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: GEORGE WATERLAND discovered sitting; his Servant JONES attending.

SP.SPEAKER: Jones.
SP.P: Captain Waterland is below, Sir, and wishes to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I can't see Capt. Waterland; I can see no∣body, Did not you tell him how ill I am?

SP.SPEAKER: Jones.
SP.P: I told him you was somewhat indispos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Is that all? Can you look in my face, and see the havock that disease is making, and only say I'm some∣what ind sposed¿

SP.SPEAKER: Jones.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, there are no symptoms of disease in your countenance that I can discover.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: None that you can understand I dare say, Jones; therefore let my brother up, only caution him against noise: I must not be hurried.

There is nothing I more dread than Harry Waterland's boist'rous spirits, they bear him up and crush me. Oh! how this younger brother of mine puts me down in all opinions! There's Lady Jane Danvers, tho' our marriage writings wait the signing,—takes no pains to conceal the preference she gives him over me:—he has the sile, the jest, the whispers, the familiar playful raillery; I have the graver moments, the dull yawning formalities, that seem a task of compliment—there is my malady; that's a disease for which there is no remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Heyday, brother George, what's the matter now? Is this a time to be sick, when you are on the point of marrying the finest woman in England?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You think her such I dare say; but if you love me Harry, do not speak so loud, nor tread so heavy; noises rack my brain.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I'll take care; but I hope you are not really indispos'd, only a little tremulous, perhaps, as the moment of your bliss approaches; were I in your case, George, my nervous system would not be a whit less unquiet than your's.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Very likely; you are an admirer of Lady Jane's.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: All the world admires her.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Happy woman! You attended her to the play last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat
SP.P: I did so; and by the way did you hear of the fracas I got into with a quarelsome fellow in the lobby?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Not I; but what is that when you've so fine a lady in your charge? A quarrel is the luckiest thing in life, sets off your gallantry, makes her the talk of the town, and you the happy favourite of the fair whom you defend.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: If I thoughi it would do that with the lady I had the honour to defend, O George, how I happy should I be.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No more upon this subject if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Well, I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You certainly do not know the state of my feel∣ings, or you would not sport with them as you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Say no more brother, I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I don't wish to be told of the charms of Lady Jane: no man can keep the affections of a woman, whose charms all other men are praising: I want no idol for the world to worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Few men in love have your philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I'm not in love; with beauty at least I'm not in love; a sympathizing tender friend is what I want: my health is gone; was Lady Jane design'd by nature to nurse a bed-rid cripple?

SP.SPEAKER: Jones.
SP.P: Lady Jane Danvers is at the door, and desires to know if you are dispos'd to accompany her to Hyde-park this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Impossible! Tell Lady Jane I am not able to stir out of my chair: go, tell her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Come, come, don't alarm her with such a message; jump up and tell her so yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, I am at this instant so totally beref of all my faculties, that I do not think I cou'd rise from this seat, if the room were in flames.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Alas! poor George, then I must leave you, forpositively I must see Lady Jane.

SP.SPEAKER: Gearge.
SP.P: Hold, Sir! I bar that interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Astonishing! Are you in your senses?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Perhaps not; but I have so much reason left, as serves me to dscover what this meeting leads to.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Then you must have an intuition superna∣tural—in the mean while you have found your legs, and yet the house is not on fire. I give you joy of your reco∣very.

SP.SPEAKER: Jones.
SP.P: Lady Jane Danvers is coming up the stairs, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: This is too glaring—too barefac'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: What is the matter? For the love of heaven, Mr. Waterland, tell me what has happen'd to you; are you wounded—are you hurt? I understood from your ser∣vant, you was not able to stir.
No answer; what is the meaning of all this? Can you explain it to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Not I; he seems very irritable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Have you had any difference—what has ruffled him?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I know not; but if you please I will leave you together: I rather think I am unwelcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Don't leave the house; I have something to say to you about last night's affair.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: [rising and advancing] Right, madam, 'tis but justice to reward the gallant champion, who turns out in the defence of beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: You know the story then it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: All the town knows it, or will know it, when so fair a lady is the object of a quarrel in a public theatre, and her hero gains such honor and such favor by defending her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: And do you from your knowledge of the lady, think that Harry's gallantry last night advanc'd him in her favor?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I'm sure it did, and think such favor cheaply purchas'd at the risk of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: You do?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: By heaven I do: I never own'd a drop of blood, that I would not have shed in her defence; but when I find myself thrown off at distance from all hope, and see those eyes bestow their smiles on him, whose slightest glance would penetrate my heart—'tis torture, 'tis distraction: I am lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Why this it is then that destroys your health, these are your sufferings, this is your distemper.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: This and none else—Go, madam, go to my hap∣py brother; bear him the beauteous prize he fought for, but tell him, when I yield you up—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P:
Me, me! yield me to Harry Waterland?
Hold there, my friend, I have not given my consent to that, and he'll not thank you for the compliment.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What do you mean? Of whom but you have I been speaking?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: If you have heard the story you must know Laetitia Rayner was the beauteous prize for which your bro∣ther fought.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: He did not tell me that—And you believ'd that I was suffering all these agonies for Laetitia—Oh, Lady Jane, am I so little known to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Oh! Mr. Waterland, am I so totally un∣known to you—jealous of your brother?—Fie for shame!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I can't deny it:—circumstances stagger'd me; Harry is a fine fellow; his gaiety amuses you; my dullness damps your spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: To say the truth, since you took this freak of jealousy into your head, you have not been the liveliest company in the world;—but now let us go to this formi∣dable rival of your's, who is dying to hear some news of Laetitia; and if whispering in a corner raises your bile, de∣pend upon it we shall give you enough to colour your com∣plexion before long.
SP.STAGE: An Apartment in Diana Grampus's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What was this affair that happen'd at the play last night with Lady Jane Danvers and you? Tell me what it was without any prevarication or disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: There is no occasion for any, madam. A drunken fellow in the lobby, as we were passing to our coach, was insolent, and the gentleman, who had charge of Lady Jane, corrected him: I believe it is no uncommon case.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Was he insolent to Lady Jane, or to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: I confess it was to me, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: And who was the gentlemen that corrected this offender?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Captain Waterland.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I guess'd as much; the younger brother of her ladyship's enamorato; a proper champion truly to take up your quarrels, and spread your name about the town as the protegee of a young rake in the guards, who is first to fight for you, and then graft pretensions upon his gal∣lantry.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: I don't believe Captain Waterland's character warrants any such interpretation.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You don't believe!—Miss Laetitia Rayner, of the discreet age of eighteen, and heiress to a great fortune, does not believe that Captain Waterland. a young officer in the guards, and heir to no fortune at all, has any other motive for standing forth in her defence, but merely to shew his valor and protect the friend of Lady Jane Dan∣vers:—now then we are at issue—here is Miss Laetitia's opinion on one side, and her aunt's on the other.—Let the world decide between us!

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Pardon me, madam, I never presume to oppose my opinion to your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Then if mine's to prevail, it will be that you ne∣ver again are seen of Lady Jane's party to a play; and that you never admit the visit of Captain Waterland in this house, or meet him in any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: You first command I certainly can obey; your second I may innocently transgress.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Lest that should happen, I shall require of you to deny yourself the supreme felicity of visiting Lady Jane.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Very well, madam; it must be as you please.
SP.STAGE: Sir TOBY GRAMPUS, and Squire ROBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Oh! my dear, dear sister—

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You are welcome to town, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I'm charm'd to see you; and how have you been this many a long day? Why, you look vastly well, grown quite plump, and protest it becomes you. Bob, make your reverence to your aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Reverend aunt, how goes it with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P:
So! here is room indeed for amendment, bro∣ther: the Graces will have work enough on their hands
before they can mould this clay into courtesy. I am afraid my friend Robert is as mere a bumpkin as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I hope not,—I hope not. I have done my best for him; taken this long journey purposely to consult you how to proceed in his education.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I never heard he had any education.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: His mother to be sure did keep him too much at home; but then t'was all repaid to us in his morals; there we gain'd every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: His morals, indeed! Take my word for it the morals of Monmouthshire won't keep long in the atmos∣phere of London.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Well, Bob, why so silent?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I'm on the safe side for that, father.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Why you are not the worse company for it at present, nephew Robert; when you come home from your travels, you will have something to tell us worth our hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Yes, most travellers have.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I have made it my business, brother, to seek out a proper Governor to accompany him on his tour: a learned person of my acquaintance, himself a travell'd man, has recommended a young gentleman of talents by the name of Crotchet: I have not seen him, but from his friend's report I augur well of his qualifications,

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I hope to goodness he is not one of your prim pe∣dantic chaps, that are only fit to chop logic, and cap verses.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Quite the reverse; diametrically opposite to that character, he describes him to be gay, facetious, easy and well-bred; a man in short of the world, who rather strives to hide his learning, than make a parade of it: Mr. Ful∣some tells me that I should not find out in a twelvemonth's acquaintance with him, that he understood one word of Greek or Latin.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I am sure I should not.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Young?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: A youth, but manly, discreet, and strictly mo∣ral.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Of a good family?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Very antient, but decay'd: of the Crotchets of Cornwall, a Saxon family, long antecedent to the Norman Conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: He'll do, he'll do; he's the very man that will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Pray, aunt, did you ask if he can sound the French horn?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: The French horn, child! why do you ask that?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Because father says I am to go up the river Nile, and the French horn sounds well upon a water party.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: The river Nile indeed! The river Tiber will be the boundary of your peregrinations: in Rome you will contemplate the venerable remains of antient magnificence; there you will tread on classic ground, and repose yourself on the bosoms of the arts and the muses.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Oh! charming. I shall sleep most deliciously.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: There, whilst you perambulate the celebrated Pantheon.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I thought it was burnt down, aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Pooh!

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I protest to you, sister Di, I was in the same error with son Bob.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You were indeed, and in error you will both re∣main:—Like father, like son; very suitably adapted to the latitude of Monmouthshire, but most lamentably unquali∣fied to breathe the pure aether of Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Mr. Fulsome to wait upon you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Is there a gentleman with him, a young gentle∣man?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: There is, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Shew them up.
Sir Toby, I must request that you will delegate this con∣ference to me without any interruption on your part, which can only puzzle and impede the negociation.
SP.STAGE: FULSOME, JACK, Sir TOBY, SQUIRE ROBERT, DIANA.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Most incomparable lady, I have the honour with profound respect to present to you my friend Mr. Crotchet, who is ambitious to prove himself worthy of being consi∣dered as your protogee, and most devoted servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P:
Mr. Fulsome, I can truly assure you that there is no person in the whole circle of the literati, under whose auspices a new acquaintance can come so recommended to
me, as when presented by your hand, and back'd by you testimony.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Your approbation, Madam, is fame, and your pa∣tronage fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Zooks! I shall never keep pace with this.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Do you mind this, Bob? this is true breeding—listen, my good boy, and learn.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Look, father, look! that fellow's back is made of whalebone: Shall I ever make such a bow as my tutor does? not I to the Pope of Rome himself. Egad, he must lift up his toe pretty high, if I am to kiss it.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Hold your tongue and observe your aunt; the Pope's a ninny to her; she carries it bravely: 'Fore George, she's an honour to the name of Grampus.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I understand your delicacy, Mr. Crotchet. By referring me to your friend you avoid self flattery: it im∣presses me in your tavor.—I love humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I persuade myself you do, and let me hope you will permit humility at all due distance to love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! sentiments so elegantly couch'd must ever be pleasing—Here is your pupil, if you can inspire him with you address.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: How long has he been in your society, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: A few minutes only; he's but now arriv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Then there is some hope: had be been a single day in your company unreform'd of his rusticity, I should have despair'd of rendering him any service.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I give you joy, brother; I flatter myself we are in a right train.
SP.STAGE: [apart to Sir Toby in a whisper.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack,
SP.P: Will it do Fulsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Admirably; you have hook'd her. Go on and prosper.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Never fear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I am told you are a perfect master of the learn∣ed languages.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I am so far master of them that I keep them at a a proper distance: There is nothing I so much abhor as bringing them into the company of the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: They'll furnish many pleasing meditations when you are upon classic ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Very possibly, at present I've no call for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Permit me to ask which of the Roman poets is your favorite?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Oh! the vengeance.—Which of the Roman poets do I prefer? really there are so many of them that I am rather puzzled to say which is best, but I think, take him for all in all, Elzevir is the fairest type.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Elzevir! I apprehend he was no poet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: True, Madam, but he was a printer of the poets, and my friend thought you was enquiring which edition he prefers. Horace I know is his poet: he and I have many amicable disputes about our respective favorites, Horace and Virgil.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Yes, yes, but we won't dispute about them now.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: What a vast fund of learning my sister Di is possest of.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Do you think it does her any good, father?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I have a slight acquaintance with the Latin tongue; Mr. Crotchet will greatly oblige me if he will repeat an ode of Horace—any one you like best, Sir, they are equal to me; I have no preference.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Nor I, Heaven knows! Fulsome, help me off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Now Crotchet, I stand a fair chance of my pe∣nalty, and if you spout one line of Latin in this lady's com∣pany, before Heaven I'll exact it.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What do you mean by that, may I ask?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Only that he is bound to me, Madam, in the pe∣nalty of an hundred pounds if he talks Latin in the ladies company. 'T was a trick he had when he came fresh from college, and so to break him of it altogether, I laid him under this forfeiture: Now as I think he can hardly resist your commands, I stand fair for my hundred pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: On no account will I permit it: I withdraw the Ode of Horace, and think that if there was a trace of pedantry in your friend's character, you cou'd not take a better method for curing a bad habit. And now, Mr. Crotchet, let me introduce you to Sir Toby Grampus and my nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P:
Learned Sir, I'm your very humble servant. I un∣derstand you are of an ancient house in Cornwall; I respect antiquity of family: The Grampus's are not mushrooms,
they did not spring up in a day. Bob, make your bow to Mr. Crotchet.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Give me your hand—If you and I are to be friends and cronies, the sooner we get rid of ceremony the better. I am overjoyed to hear you are bound not to talk Latin.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: To the ladies, remember. To the learned Dons in Italy, Latin or Greek, or what they like best ▪ It's all one to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: A gentleman at the door wishes to speak a word in private to Mr. Fulsome upon particular business.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Madam, I ask a thousand pardons for such a free∣dom: I don't know what gentleman can have particular business with me. Did he give you his name?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: No, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: No apologies, Mr. Fulsome.—Shew the gen∣tleman into the parlour.
Come we will adjourn to the library; I must shew Mr. Crotchet my collection.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Is your name Fulsome, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: My name is Fulsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: And is this your ticket?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: This is my ticket—My name is upon it, and my place of abode.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Was you at the theatre, last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: I was at no theatre: I am not in the habit of fre∣quenting them.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I perceive I am betrayed into a mistake: You certainly are not the person who delivered this ticket to me in the lobby last night in consequence of a little fra∣cas. If you know any person likely to have made free with your name in that way, I shou'd be glad you wou'd direct me to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P:
Upon my word it is impossible for me to say where
I may have dropt a ticket of this sort, or who may have found it. My acquaintance is pretty numerous, and as I guess the purport of your enquiry, I shou'd be loth to fix it upon any one in particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: The person my affair was with is a young man, speaks quick, was fluster'd with liquor, and dress'd in a pale green frock with a scarlet work'd waistcoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: I know no gentleman of my acquaintance, who an∣swers to your description in dress or otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Sir, I am satisfied and ask pardon for the trouble I have given you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Your most obedient. Oh! Jack, Jack, these tricks will blow you up at last.
SP.STAGE: LAETITIA runs in and stops short.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Is it possible? May I believe my eyes? Miss Rayner!

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Didn't you know I liv'd here with my aunt?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Not I, by Heavens! Have you recover'd your alarm?

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Yes, yes, but there's no time for questions. I must not stay with you another minute: My aunt will not allow me to receive your visits.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: May I not hope to meet you then at Lady Jane's?

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Never; that house is interdicted also. Come, come begone!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Cannot I form some pretence for waiting upon you? You have taken my heart from me; am I not allow'd to follow it? My person is not known to your aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Your name's enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I'll forswear it for the sight of you. I'll turn to any shape, name, character or condition but to look upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: In the first place then, stifle your affair of last night, let us hear no more of that idle quarrel. If it gets wind, I am undone. Promise me this.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: By all that's beautiful!

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Stop Lady Jane from coming hither: Tell her the interdict that I am under. If you are going to her now perhaps you will hear of me—Fly!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I do fly from all that is lovely under Heaven,

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: To Lady Jane's.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: To Lady Jane's. Farewell!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: A Room in Lady Jane's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Not to keep you longer on the tenters, I have something to communicate to you; an epistle enigma∣tic, deep, mysterious; yet without the wit of oedipus you may make shift to unriddle it; the writer we'll suppose to be a certain young lady, whom Captain Waterland has no chance for visiting without a stratagem. I'll read it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Oh Heavens! I'm all impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Oh Heavens! I do not doubt it.
SP.Q: “My aunt has been closely occupied with chusing a tutor for my cousin Robert: I have only caught a glimpse of him, but I am persuaded he is the very” fellow who annoy'd us at the play▪—

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: The devil he is—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Do keep the devil down and listen—
SP.Q:
“He is in high favour and has undertaken to provide a fencing master for his pupil; if your friend Cap∣tain Waterland knows any professor of the noble science, that he wou'd wish to introduce into my aunt's house, he may easily contrive to take the re∣commendation out of this fellow's hands by ma∣naging
his secret, and if the fencer is a real master of his art and is nimble in his attack, I shall not be sorry to be present at a lecture.”

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Oh! ye loves and graces, all the wits of all the world, never compounded any thing one half so ex∣quisite. Dear, dear, adorable Lady Jane, what a celestial friend you are! I'll run home this instant, dress myself in character, take my foils under my arm, post away to aunt Di, send for my Box-Lobby Challenger, make him swear I'm the best master living, or ring off his ears close to his head and baulk the pillory of its prey.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: How now, Jack! Well met. Dosey and I were coming to your friend Fulsome's to enquire after you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Were you so, were you so? Hope you've had a pleasant walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Is that all you have to say to us?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: No, 'tis not all—Hope you'll have a pleasant walk back again, for I'm not at Fulsome's.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: I see you are not.—But how goes your affair at the Grampus's? Tell us that, lad; for we are impatient to hear about it: Will it do, will it do?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Taste it; take a pinch! I believe it will do better than the mundungus you get in Dyot-street. Treat your nostrils with a sniff.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Are you mad? Is this your way of answering my enquiries?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack
SP.P: Can't stop to talk with you in the streets—can't upon my soul! Gentlemen of my acquaintance will be passing by, and what shall I say if they should ask me who that old don was in the snuff-coloured drab, black stock∣ings and flaxen bob? Cou'dn't stand their raillery, cou'd not by all that's elegant.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: By my soul this fellow's impudence puts me down.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Law! Jacky, what a flashy box you've got.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P:
Do you like it? So do I—Safe's the word; if
any rascal was to pilfer this, 'twou'd be more than a pillory job, let me tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Rascal, reprobate, miscreant! Is this behaviour to your father? Whose money is it but mine that clothes that back of thine, which I hope some cudgell will bela∣bour? Whose industry but mine supports you in the world? whose interest but mine procur'd this situation for you; which you now, graceless upstart as you are, make a plea for putting on the man of fashion and turning your back upon your parents and benefactors?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Keep your temper, and I have something to say to you in the way of business—You shall print my Journal.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Print your dying speech and confession, that's what I'll do for you willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: You shall print my Journal; brush up your press, get a new type, work off your sheets clean, and you shall print my tour. I have made a progress in it already; I am half way up Mount Aetna; in a day or two I look to be upon the edge of the crater.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: I wou'd you was in the very centre of it.
SP.STAGE: Capt. WATERLAND after taking a view of JACK unseen, runs in and lays hold of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Have I jump'd upon you at last?—My Box-lobby friend, as I take it—the very man by all that's lucky. Come, Sir, you and I have an affair to settle.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: I'm glad of it, I'm glad of it with all my heart. 'Tis a judgement on you, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I don't know you, Sir; I don't know any busi∣ness you have with me. I never was in the box-lobby in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Oh monstrous liar! Don't let him out of your hands, Sir! He is the very man; I am his father to my sorrow, and I tell you he is they ver man.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: For shame, Mr. Crotchet, you let your revenge go too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: What do you say for yourself? Your own father witnesses against you. Come, turn out.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Let me choose my weapons then—I'll take one of these and you shall take the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P:
No, Sir, these are the implements of my
profession; these I keep for my scholars; I have a sword at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: A thousand thanks to you; but permit me to ob∣serve you was an army officer last night, this morning you are a fencing master; under favor which do you chuse to be?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Either, or both: why do you ask?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Because if you teach the sword as a professor, I'm off, 'tis no battle; if you draw as a soldier, I beg your pardon, 'tis no quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I have a rod over your head you are not aware of: the lady you affronted last night, is niece to your patroness Mrs. Diana Grampus.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Oh! my curst stars!

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: There, there! I told you how it would be.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Hold your tongue: let the gentleman proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: You have no possible way to escape, being disgraced in that quarter, but by recommending me to your pupil as a teacher of the small sword.—Here are my cre∣dentials: make your choice! If I am a fencing master, these weapons have no point; if I am an officer, my sword is through your body.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Then you are a fencing-master, and shall be a fencing-master as long as you please, and the best that ever took soil in hand; whoever says to the contrary is a puppy and a scoundrel; and I take upon me to say you shall teach my pupil as little, or as much of your art as you like.—As I flatter myself you have no designs upon old Di, if there is any thing I can serve you in with the rest of the family, I am your everlasting friend, and most devoted humble servant till death.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I have no plot upon old Di, so far I promise; more I'll impart to you as we walk to the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: By bye! light upon my legs you see—best friends in lie—call upon you some evening when the streets are empty—pleasant walk to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: If fortune carries this fellow through, she cer∣tainly must do it to put honesty out of conntenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P:
I must have some talk with you, nephew Ro∣bert;
you have no objection I should hope to take a little wholesome advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: None at all; I can swallow physic if it were to do me good.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You are now stepping upon the great stage of life; you must begin to exercise, not your limbs only, but your mental faculties; your understanding also by the help of proper tutors and preceptors. It is a sad thing you know to be the dunce of the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I mostly keep at home with father, and when both are alike, one can't complain of t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: There's a shrewd truth in that remark:—You read I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: No, I never read, I'm like father for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Nor hear others read to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: How should you get instruction else?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I ponder a pretty deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What can you ponder upon?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: All good matters; nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Well, that's not amiss; and indeed your father says you are a very orderly moral young man.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Remarkably so.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You don't fall in with the vices of the time?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Can't endure to hear of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Never drink, nor swear, nor use bad words.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Never, never.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Nor quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Never quarrel, but I love fighting; there can be no harm in that you know, for the best man never fails to win the battle.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Why you are a bit of a casuist, Robert; there is some ingenuity in your apology. There is one thing however above all I would guard you against in this wicked town.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: What is that, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: The company of naughty women.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P:
Oh! aunt, how it shocks me to hear you! As if I'd go to—Oh fie! that ever such a wicked thought should come into your head:—Well, if ever I could have believed that my aunt Di:—What would Mr. Crotchet
say if he heard you talk of naughty women? My good∣ness, how he does rave about you!

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: About me! Tell me what he said about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Oh! such things—dear heart, how angry you would be if I were to tell you all!

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Nay, but tell me all; tell me what he says.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: He says—let me see—he says, “he could sit the whole day long and hear you talk”—not about naughty women I should think—“that he would rather be your” servant and wait upon you, than my master with my father's fortune at command"—that's not so civil to me you know:—in short, he says, "you are an angel."

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Does he say that?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Yes he does, and more than that; but I must not repeat it to you, for it's a paugh word.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I can't believe it, therefore let me have it, what∣ever it is.

P.Q: Well then, he says, “He had rather take you in your smock.”

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Ah! frightful—he did'nt say smock; I'm sure he did not say that.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Why then, if it was not smock, it was shift; I won't swear which:—but hush! here he comes; don't blab now, dear aunt!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Do I intrude? Dismiss me if I'm troublesome.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: That can hardly be; Robert and I have been moralizing upon the times. You are the pilot to steer him through the rocks and shoals; I have only pointed out on the chart where they lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: 'Tis a dangerous channel; I have navigated it with care, know the buoys and bearings, and have sounded every inch of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: So young and yet so sage? I should be curious to know by what happy management you got this perfect knowledge of the dangers without buying your experience at the usual price.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P:
By never being the dupe of what the world calls love; there is all my art. Love is the one fatal rock on which most adventurers split: By properly estimating what it ought to be, I have never suffered by what it is: I hold
it for a sublime, a sacred passion; I reserve myself for some∣thing more than mere frail mortality; the woman that captivates me, must have a strong trait of the angelic in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Mark that, aunt Di, he'll fit you with a pair of wings.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: The sighs of vapours, the languishings of those irrationals, who call themselves lovers, have been my jest and ridicule.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Have you never been in love in your life then? Come, be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: You should have ask'd me that awhile ago; the question now is out of time.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Egad, you're a deep one.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: It might favor of vanity were I to say how easily I carry all attacks: Indeed they know me now well enough to know they wou'd but lose their labour: Rank they are convinced cannot flatter me, riches cannot bribe, a pretty face makes no impression, and a simpleton disgusts me: In short, after weathering the storm upon the high seas, it is my fate to be shipwreckt in the harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I rather think 'twill be your fate to get into the harbour and moor close along side of the hulk.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Pray, aunt Di, may'nt I see cousin Robert fight with the fencing master? They have nobs upon their swords, so they cannot hurt each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What are you talking of, child, about fighting and fencing masters?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I can explain it to you. I have got a fencing master for my pupil, one that I have known for many years and can recommend; not a foreign puppy, but a solid, quiet, unpretending man: I always look to the principles as well as to the performances of a teacher.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Oh! if you have got a fighting master, let him come on; I am his man at that sport; cudgells, quarter∣staff, or what he will. Cousin Laetitia, I hope you'll be of the party. Aunt Di, you won't say nay—

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: 'Tis not quite a lady's amusement methinks, but if you desire it, Laetitia, you may go with your cousin. The eye of the fair may animate the clown.
SP.STAGE: [A Servant delivers a Card to Laetitia.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: A card to me!—“Captain Waterland presents” his compliments to Miss Rayner and will be happy to hear she has not suffered from her alarm last night.—Pooh! tell the servant it requires no answer.—Is that right aunt?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Perfectly right, and the only answer it deserves; I am pleased to see you follow my advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: I am very happy that you approve of me.—Come, cousin Robert, don't let us keep the fighting man any longer waiting. I dare say, aunt, you wonder at my taste, for I know you can't bear such fights; you always hide your eyes when they fight on the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana
SP.P: I do so, my dear, I do so: My nerves are ex∣tremely delicate; every body in their own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Very true, and yet you see I have no design to be a soldier's wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I believe, Mr. Crotchet, your attendance may be disposed with, to form the manners, not to teach the ex∣ercises is your tsk, and no light one let me tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Whilst I am cheer'd with your support I feel it light; when that is lost, I must sink under it.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: That you will never lose; his clownishness I fear is too inveterate.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Stubborn enough, I dare say, but I apprehend more trouble to myself in preventing new habits than in getting rid of old ones. I have discover'd some symptoms already that are rather alarming.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What do you allude to in particular?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Principally in his manner towards the ladies; he has a way of deporting himself in the company of young women, which I am sure you would not approve of.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: As how I pray? explain it to me, that I may assist in the correction of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I hardly know how to explain it by words, but if I might take the liberty of shewing you what I mean by imitation, I cou'd make myself understood.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: By all means; actions of this sort can be no otherwise described.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: In the first place then—when a handsome woman falls in his way, instead of regarding her with a look, such as I now address to you, modest, respectful, unimpassion'd; on the contrary he stops, stares, rivers his eyes on her's in the eager manner, as for example's sake I do on your's, and looks as he would look her through.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Oh Heavens! can he look so?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack
SP.P: Now that you know is not proper and decorus.—

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: There's a very sensible difference between one look and the other as you rightly exemplify. But surely in your case the copy far outgoes the original; his eyes have no expression, your's are all on fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: 'Twas caught from what they look'd on: there was a sympathetic glance went to my heart. We must not practise that again; I shall offend.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: And I shall pardon;—pray proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: So, so! the old touch wood has caught fire.—Then again, if he is to take a lady's hand for the purpose of con∣ducting her out of the room, or to her carriage, we'll say—ought it not to be touched lightly, delicately, devoutly, in this fashion with one hand; and not seiz'd violently with both in this warm impetuous manner, as if he was going to hurry her into a post chaise for an elopement?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Just so; I feel what you mean exactly—and then his boisterous mode of saluting—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: That I did not see, how was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: In the country custom, with both arms round my neck and a loud smack upon my cheek.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: What! thus for instance—

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: No, no; worse than that.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Oh horrible! what, quite as bad as this?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Yes, quite as bad. He must be broke of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: And so must I, or perish at your feet, unless you pity and forgive.—Oh! thou first only idol my soul 'ere worshipt; from this moment I renounce your nephew; never will I be exiled from your sight, tho' hopeless to ob∣tain what I adore; never will I travel over one inch of ground with that young clown; honor compels me to de∣clare to you I never meant to do it; nay more, it obliges me to confess that I am an impostor.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: An impostor!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Yes, loveliest of women, for your sake I am an impostor, falsely pretending to stoop my proud spirit to the servile office of tutoring a dunce, when my ambition was to approach a divinity, whom I had hitherto only admired at a distance. This was the deceit I practis'd, and know that one, who carries up his pedigree to centuries above the conquest, never will descend to barter independence for an office, scarcely above menial: Here then it ex∣pires; from your hands I received it, at your feet I surrender it.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Not at my feet; it melts my heart to see a man so noble, so disinterested, so worthy all my tenderest sen∣timents, in that submissive posture.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Ah! madam, it would melt your heart, did you know all my story—born to better hopes, educated by the most indulgent parents with the fondest care; son of a father, whose public spirit drew him forth into the post of danger, and after raising him above the heads of his admiring countrymen, exposed him, as it were, upon a scaffold, to the taunts and malice of his unrelenting enemies—I can∣not bear to name particulars; my tongue shrinks back with horror; vice triumph'd, virtue bled; his manly spi∣rit, still unbroken, stem'd the rage of mobs; he fac'd his foes and fell—The best of parents fell—I can no more.—I think the pillory owes me a good turn for that pa∣negyrick.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, you have a friend that shares in all your sorrows—How sweet is filial piety! how touching, how endearing are those tears!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Oh! let me vent them on your sympathising bo∣som! here let me lie and breathe my last, expiring with excess of love amidst a paradise of sweets.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I cannot stand this tenderness; it banishes re∣serve—Tell me in one word—Are you sincere?—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Is truth itself to be believ'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Faithful and secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Faithful as the pole-star, secret as the center.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Then take this ring—with it I pledge my heart, my hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Stop there, I ask no more; you must not name your fortune; my soul disdains the sordid lures of nte∣rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Then be it as you wish; I'll not contaminate your purity of sentiment with worldly offers—we'll only talk of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Egad! I am a little sorry for that though—I have gone too far— (aside.) Come, I was too susceptible; say what was in your thoughts: love will be lord of every hour; to worldly matters we'll devote but minutes—May I procure the license?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Heavens! how you set my heart a throbbing!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Pretty flutterer! busy anxious thing! throbbing with generous zeal to lavish all on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I give myself; the rest is trash, and, as you rightly say, what a soul like your's disdains.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I wish I had not thought about my soul at that moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You must be husht in this matter as death itself; you see this girl Laetitia, she's my ward, and a rich hei∣ress: I had a wish to marry her to my nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: 'Twill never do; you'll never bring her to endure a clown.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I own it does not promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: It is not in your nature to force her affections; so generous in your own, you cannot be so rigid over her's. Give her the man she likes, provided he's a gen∣tleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: And let her marry first.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Humph! is that necessary?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: 'Twill be decorous at least, seeing I am her guardian: But come, step to the library with me; there we shall be more private; our conference here is liable to observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Victoria! I have won the fleece, and in faith it is a warm one.

SP.STAGE: Squire ROBERT stript to his waistcoat, his coat hung upon a frame, at which he is pushing with his foil. Captain WATERLAND and LAETITIA in con∣versation apart.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Aha! there I had you—Oho! there I hit you.—How many more times must I pink this fellow in the turnip-colour'd doublet? Methinks he looks as if he had enough of it. What say you, Laetitia? Is your lecture pretty well over? If all mine are to be like this, which will make the quickest progress, you or I?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Oh! thou art a dear good natur'd soul, and I shall love thee for this the longest hour I have to live.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: You love indeed! All your love is bespoke, and what you can spare to me, will be no more than cousinly kindness. Now may I be further, if I can guess for the heart of me what you two can have found to say to each other all this while—jabber, jabber, without one moment's ceasing. When I make love, it's at a word—will you? says I—Nay, says she; let it alone, quoth I, go hang! there's an end of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: But perhaps I did not answer in that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I believe not in faith; you don't look as if you cou'd say nay to your lover; but what then? One way is as short as t'other. If you know one another's mind, what need of more words? I may fence to the day of Jerusalem; one hit is as good as an hundred, if it does but take place in the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: May I perish, Squire, if you are not this moment in all England the very best fellow breathing.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P:
I won't say that; all England's a wide place; but what then? I am a good fellow, I know that well enough: Never make no speeches to me; I'm downright, and afore the wind. They think I can't see the length of my nose, but I can py more than they are aware of. Why, as if I didn't smoke old Di and the Doctor over∣head; 'tis all the same game on that floor as you are play∣ing
on this, and I dare say it holds through from the kitchen to the garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Why, you are a wit, cousin Bob.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: A wit am I? And if you was a wit too, how cou'd you help it? I'll tell you another thing, that per∣haps you think I hadn't sense to find out—Old D wants to put you and me together—Lord help you, that wou'd never do. What shou'd I make of all that frippery in the country? every hedge stake would have a pluck at it: No, no; I must have a tight truss'd thing, brac'd like a pudding∣bag; a kind of road-tit, that can go over rough ground; those galloping fetlocks of your's wou'd hang cruelly in the soil; mercy on me, you'd be pull'd all to pieces, and done up in one season.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Well then, Robert, you and I will part by cousent, and live good friends asunder for the rest of our lives. You shall have your Momouthshire milk-maid of the true poney stamp, and I will take my chance upon the smooth turf, which you seem to think is what I'm fittest for. Hush! here comes Mr. Crotchet—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: My dear friends, I match a moment to whisper one word in your ear.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Speak out; we are all in confidence,

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: This it is; if I augur rightly, you will not long have any occasion to bring your foils with you when you visit in this family, if I am not cross'd in my endeavours, a certain gentleman, who sent his card of compliments not long ago, will very soon be permitted to make his visit in person. Ask not by what means this is brought about; believe only that where I profess a friendship, it is not for a small matter that I will break my world.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I dare say your are a man of honour, Mr. Crotchet, and I shall act with you as such.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Trust me only, and you shall never be deceiv'd: you too, my worthy pupil, yu shall confess I am your friend; and as for you, Miss Rayner, if you do not very shortly find yourself set free from all restrictions, say I am no Prophet.—This gentleman I would advise to beat his march immediately, and that his person may not be notic'd by the servants, I will let him out of the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I'll be gone this moment. Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Where shall I wait upon you? I must have a few minutes with you in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Here is my direction:—Hold though! Let me be sure I've given you the right ticket: these cards you know are liable to be mistaken. That's between you and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Well, well, it's all fair: I deserve that; but er∣rors excepted, you know is a salvo for all accounts, be they ever so honest.
SP.STAGE: (Capt. Wat. and Jack go one way; Loetitia and the Squire another,

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Well, Harry, what success with your fen∣cing-master?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Beyond my hopes:—I fenc'd my way into the house; parried all difficulties, disarm'd aunt Di; laid the Box-lobby champion at my feet, and I flatter myself plac'd a gentle hit or two on the soft heart of my lovely Laetitia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: But was it a hit, a palpable hit, as Ostrick says? It so, I pronounce that the Lord Hamlet shall win.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I will if I can, for in faith it will be a prize worth fighting for; I am all over wounds from head to heart, tho' she has only play'd her small artillery on me yet. I have a notable good second in cousin Bob, the young Grampus, and plenty of fair promises from the box∣lobby quarter, but these I cannot swear for. Time will shew.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: May I come in?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: No, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Your door says yes, for it is most invitingly open.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Whose fault was that, Harry, your's or mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I scorn to make gentlemen jealous; it ruins the complexion; gives them ad sorder in their eyes, and takes away the use of their limbs. I have seen very bad effects from it:—A friend of mine was so totally crippled by a fit of jealousy, that he cou'd not rise from his seat if the room had been in flames.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then I'll venture to say he was most thoroughly in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: And probably with some good-for-nothing jilt, who was not worth the pains that he bestowed upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Why should the fault be her's? The man perhaps thought humbly of himself, and trembled at the chance of her discovering superior merit in a rival. Now if you had such a lover as this, Lady Jane, could you be very angry with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Outrageously, and I would torment him most deliciously.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Cou'd you find in your heart to do that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Oh yes, I have no mercy upon jealousy.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And how wou'd you set about punishing him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Why, I wou'd lay out for some such idle stray fellow as Harry here for instance, whom no woman in her senses can be serious about; and none but such a chit as Laetitia cou'd be taken in by.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
