SP.P: Do you hear her, brother George, do you hear her? If this does not prove that I am uppermost in her thoughts, what can prove it? And why does she abuse poor dear Laetitia, but because she can't endure to see me like any body but herself?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: How come you then to trust your cause to an advocate so suspicious? Had'nt you better employ me, who am certainly interested to dispose of you? Send me to the lady of your heart, and let me plead in your behalf.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I bar that experiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: And I also.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Let me have no unmarried elder brother my counsel with Laetitia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: And let not the man whom I wou'd attach, come within the sphere of her fascinating eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Be just to yourself Lady Jane, and you can ne∣ver be suspicious of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Miss Rayner to wait upon your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Very well; shew Miss Rayner up.
Come, come, gentlemen, I shall not let you stay here: go into that room, and wait till I come to you:—no wry faces Harry, but be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: My dear Laetitia!

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: My dearest Lady Jane, aunt Di is grown so good humour'd, I have leave to come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: I am glad to see you have surviv'd your alarm at the theatre; but you will soon be able to fight your own battles, as I understand you are taking lectures in the noble science of defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Oh yes, I have an admirable master; he takes great pains with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: And you improve I dare say to his wishes; no doubt he is ver fond of his disciple.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: He flatters me by telling me so—And shall I believe him, Lady Jane? You have experience of the fa∣mily, and can tell me if sincerity runs in the blood of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: There is, indeed, one of the firme, as the traders call it, whom I have had some transactions with, and find him a fai-dealing honest man: There is good property in the partnership, and I fancy you may trust the house: But what says your aunt to it? I rather suspect she wishes you to give your custom to her nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Perhaps so, but his stock is small, and of a fashion that does not suit my taste; I am releas'd from that engagement, and she won't over-rule me in any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Then suffer me to recommend a friend of mine, who waits with a throbbing heart behind that door, impatient to throw himself at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: What do you mean? you startle me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Not much, I hope—
SP.STAGE: [Goes into the room, and returns, presenting Captain Waterland.
SP.P: 'Tis only your poor fencing-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: You take me by surprize—so great a master of his art shou'd scorn to attack a feeble fencer unpre∣par'd I shou'd have time at least to guard my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I only come to fall before your feet, and beg for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Rise, rise, if you expect me to converse with you; I'll not listen to any thing you say upon your knees. If Lady Jane is always to keep you in her cabinet ready to sally forth, and fasten on a harmless creature, who is de∣coyed into her snare, have you the conscience to expect I will humour your vanity by repeating these visits? espe∣cially when my aunt has taken off the interdict, and opens her doors to Captain Waterland in common with every other man of fashion, who has a claim to visit her.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: And may I visit her?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: But do you wish it?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: What an insidious question!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: I was excluded personally; what can have softened her heat?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Love, mollifying love. Our playhouse quarrel has been productive of wonderful events; one party is on the point of carrying off the aunt, and I dare say you think the other is in no bad train for carrying off the niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Alas! how very far am I from such pre∣sumptuous hopes, when all I sue for is not to be con∣demned to absolute despair?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Poor man! you have an advocate in Lady Jane; go to her, tell her how little she consults your in∣terest by her absence; confess how very ill you manage your own cause, and how totally you despair of ever soften∣ing my hard heart without her help.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P:
Not whilst that lovely smile encourages my hope will I resort to any advocate for help: With nothing else to recommend me but a heart and soul devoted to
you I throw myself upon your generosity without appeal, and by your sentence I will stand or fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: But I'm not in the humour to pass sentence upon you just now; therefore we'll break up the court and go to Lady Jane.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Will you be gone so soon?

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Why not, since now there are no obstructions to our meeting; and if I was not sincere enough to own how welcome you will be to me, you wou'd be too saga∣cious not to discover that I play'd the hypocrite.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Then I am blest indeed: That confession has inspir'd me with such transports, that I dare not give them utterance, yet know not how to suppress them.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Then I'll teach you what to do with them—When a subject is too interesting, I drive it from my thoughts; when a lover is too agreeable, I run away from him—follow my example—but hold, hold!—Don't run the same way.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Can I help it? My heart is in your chains, and I must follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Oh! you simple man, this is making bad worse; fly to the other door, if you mean to escape!

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: You wou'd despise me if I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Laetitia.
SP.P: Well, perhaps I shou'd—so come along with me to Lady Jane.
SP.STAGE: JACK CROTCHET is discovered reading a parchment;

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Well, have you read it over?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Do you approve what it contains?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Your word had been as good.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P:
My word indeed might well have pass'd 'twixt you and me, but when relations, who are interested to keep me single, beset me with their importunity, this deed will be my answer. The obligation there to marry you
under the penalty of ten thousand pounds, will silence all opposers, and when they see, that with your free consent I've made my nephew Robert heir to all my property, one poor annuity excepted of four hundred pounds a year to you at my decease, what can they do but own your con∣duct truly generous and disinterested?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Madam, I have my faults like other men; you'll hear of them from many mouths that will open against me; you'll find them out yourself, but amongst them all, you never will discover me to be an interested, sordid, sneaking fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I'll pledge my life you are not.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: No, hang it, that's a character I hold in sovereign contempt. Covetousness has not even the credit of being the vice of a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I dare be sworn you have no vice at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Don't risque that oath; you wou'd not like me half so well if I was all milk and honey. I hope you also have a little of the acid, how shall we else keep up the nuptial appetite unpall'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Come, come, you ramble.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I have a little turn for that to be sure, but then I'm always merry when I come home, and that makes up for every thing. The best thing I can say for myself is, that no man bears chiding with a better grace; tell me of my faults over and over again, rate and rattle at me ever so often, I am still the same, it makes no change in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Mr. Crotchet, are you serious? Your stile is really so new to me, so very much unlike what you held in our first conversations, that you alarm me most exceedingly: Tell me what you are aiming at by this kind of dis∣course?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: To let you into my character, and get a peep at your's: We have pass'd the stage of love, and there's no longer any call upon us to deceive each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Then I will tell you, Sir, that my character is that, which will neither put up with an insolent lover nor a libertine husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P:
Right, nor can I bear a tame, civil, submissive wife; give me a woman of spirit; let her tongue be heard in the house: I love the high notes of the female voice, 'tis music to my ears—so now, my lovely dear betroth'd,
adieu! I'll take the sacred scroll, that makes us one, and treasure it as your gift.—So! this is done, firm as the law can bind.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I'm petrified! I stand aghast at what I've done. He's chang'd, transform'd; no longer like the man he was—no warmth, no gratitude, no fondness—not so much as a look—I thought to have seen him kneeling at my feet, gazing upon me with uplifted doating eyes, then starting up with rapture on the sudden and enfolding me in his arms.—Oh Heavens! what ails me? am I alter'd? am I less pleasing, less alluring than I was? Now, brother, what's the news with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Damnable bad news for some ofus—a famous kettle of fish you have made of it, sister Di, with this Jack Crotchet as they call him.—He a proper person to be pilot to a Grampus; zooks! he is not fit to be the porter of a Scuttlefish.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What are you talking of? What are you bawling about? You make me mad, you turn my brain to hear your uncouth, unintelligible jargon. Speak English, if you've any thing to tell me, and let me understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Shou'd you understand me better then if I was to speak Welch? What the plague and the pesti∣lence to boot! I must talk such language as I have. What is it you would be at? Am I not going to tell, if you had but patience?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Patience!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Why aye, there is not one of my name but myself that knows what patience means. You are a true Grampus, sister Di, let me tell you, every inch a Grampus.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Will you give me what you have to say in one word, or will you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P:
I cannot for the soul of me give it you in one word, but I can tell you in much fewer words than
such a rascal deserves, that your fine fashionable fop of a tutor, your Jack Crotchet, is a pick-pocketly impostor, and instead of being the son of William the Conqueror, and the Devil knows who, is the spawn of a pillory-printer.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You have kill'd me. Call my servants, give me hartshorn, or I shall faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What the vengeance should you faint for? I've more need of hartshorn, who have beat the hoof after him till I am as weary as a hound—There I went up a crin∣kum-crankum, cutthroatly-alley out of Holborn, (hold there, it was not Holborn, it was St. Giles's) and what should I see in a shop window but a book of travels thro' Italy and the Lord knows where, by Joseph Fulsome Esquire. Oho! thought I, here's a book for Bob—so I cast my eye upon the board, and there I read in dirty capi∣tals—JOHN CROTCHET, PRINTER.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Why need you be so tedious, so circumstan∣tial? Was this John Crotchet father to my Mr. Crotchet?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: To be sure he was; he told me so himself; I bought the book of him, his name is to the receipt: I went a few doors further; I turn'd into a barber's shop, (the best place you know for news) and there enquired the character of Master Crotchet—"It's a rule with me," said the shaver, “never to speak ill of my neighbours, es∣pecially of one who is my customer, but all the world knows neighbour Crotchet was pilloried, so there's no scandal in that.”

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Stop your tongue, blundering, boisterous, un∣feeling man as you are!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Heyday! what devil drives now?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Don't you see the condition I'm in?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby
SP.P: What condition are you in? by your talk I should guess you have been a little in the sun, as the say∣ing is.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: In the sun! say rather in the shade.—Oh! that eternal night would fall upon this fatal hour, and shade it from my sight for ever! I am ruin'd and undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: The Deuce you are! Hush it up, hush it up again, for the love of mercy.—If you and pillory Jack have been—

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Worse, worse—I've married him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Toby.
SP.P: What! that's a settler, that's a knock-down blow. Good night to you! when you've thrown the stocking, truss yourself up in the garter. You'll have a notable batch of new relations.—The pillory for your fa∣ther-in-law, the whipping-post and stocks for your cousins, the gibbet for your husband, and a jointure in Botany Bay for yourself. I give you joy of your bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Stop there, the atal noose is not yet tied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: But it soon will, and when he has stretch'd the rope, you will be what they call a Tyburn widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I tell you I am not wedded; I have but pledg'd my virgin vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Then, good virgin, keep as you are; you have weather'd it a good round time, ev'n hold out to the end, and set the flesh at defiance.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Cease your licentious talk and hear me:—I have given it on my bond to forfeit ten thousand pounds upon a breach of marriage, and he has the bond.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Ten thousand devils fly away with it and him together.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: That penalty excepted, all my property is settled hard and fast upon your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Oh! is it so? Well, well, that's quite ano∣ther case. Upon my soul, I'm afraid this alarm will be the death of you—you look vastly pale: Don't you feel as if you was a going to faint? How it wou'd baulk the rascal if you was to go off suddenly!

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Monster! wou'd you murder me to get my estate? Let him be what he will, he's not a sordid, sneak∣ing, wordly-minded huncks:—He's only a rake, and I'll reform him; he's only a young rantipole young libertine, and I'll marry him in despight of you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Hell and confusion! she's only fit to be an Out-penstioner of Bedlam—Oh! are you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P:
Bob, Bob! why Bob, I say!—How like a stock you stand, do you know what has happen'd? Have
you heard the horrid news? Are you asleep, or drunk, or dead? D—n you, for a dunce, what are you a thinking of?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Nothing—Letting my understand rest—What are you talking of?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Toby.
SP.P: Why, of your aunt Di, to be sure.—She's ruin'd, ravish'd, murder'd, married, and gone to the devil.—

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Joy go with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Married to your son of a bitch of a bear-leader.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Joy go with him then! He has an arm full of it. It's no news to me, father; I cou'd have told you this an age ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Why did'nt you tell me, dunce, dolt? Then I might have stopt her in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: You wou'd, wou'd you? You'll stop the Thames next, I warrant. Laud, laud! how you fuss yourself about nothing.—Can't you let the old maid have her Crotchet, and say no more about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Was ever such an animal as my son! I sup∣pose if I had told him of her estate, he woud'nt have car'd for that either. Well, well, after all there is something to comfort us.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: So this is the way you treat me after all I have done for you, not print my treatise upon education, unless I pay you ready money for the paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Why should I give you my profit?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Why did I give you my interest with Di Gram∣pus, and promote your son to an establishment, which your utmost ambition could not have aspir'd to?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: I had no ambition about it, never ask't it of you—never wished it; my son, as you call him, is no son of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P:
Don't say, that Mr. Crotchet, he is your own true son, and as like you as he can stare; and here he comes to
prove my words.—Lord love you, Jacky, how pleas'd I am to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: How do, how do; how is it with you, Master Fulsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Master Fulsome!—I don't quite relish your famili∣arities, Sir; some of them have not been altogether so agreeable. If you chuse to take a beating over night, am I to be call'd out for it next morning? Who was that gentleman you gave my ticket to?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Harry Waterland, a particular friend of mine; I coud'nt do you more honour than lay you in to his ac∣quaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Confer no such honor upon me, if you have any re∣gard for yourself; recollect you are in my power; a word of mine blasts you beyond redemption.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Nobody's word has a happier faculty of blasting I do confess; and if you have a fancy to try it upon me, and will run the risk of an airing in a blanket, you are heartily welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: I can bear this no longer; your insolence, and your father's ingratitude, shall meet a full reward; and you shall find to your sorrow, I can be as active an enemy, as I have been a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Ah, Jack, Jack, will you never be wise? As sure as can be that spiteful man will go and betray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Very likely: let him go—Here, mother, I've a present for you; I think you took a fancy to my snuff-box. I'll give it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Will you indeed, my dear? Why that is very kind: look, husband, look what a fine present he has made me.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: You'll see it advertised in a day or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: That's your opinion, is it? Keep yourself out of an advertisement as long, and you will do well. Cast your eye over this parchment, you'll find security for the snuff-box.

SP.SPEAKER: Thcod.
SP.P: What is it, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: A trifle; some forty thousand pounds, with the in∣cumbrance of a wife, or a neat ten with a clear acquit∣tance: Now may I not set Fulsome at desiance?

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: But is it true, Jack? Is it hard and fast?

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: By the life of me, as firm as law can make it. what an unexpected stroke of fortune! 'Tis as if the sky rain'd gold:—how in the name of wonder did you persuade Di Grampus to this deed?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Dame Nature did the business; laid a train of combustibles in Diana's veins, and put the match in my hand that set fire to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Now do I repent from my heart, that we pro∣vok'd that spiteful fellow Fulsome, who will play us some dog's trick in revenge, and perhaps break off the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: But he won't break off this seal from the bond; and as for old Di, take my word for it she'll not pay sorfeit, but start the race, and run it through even to the last.—Aha! my little novelist!

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Oh Lindamira, I've such news to tell you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Hush, mother, hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Such a piece of good fortune—your friend Jack is going to be married to Mrs. Diana Grampus with a monstrous fortune;—the wedding clothes are bought, the equipage bespoke, and there's the licence in Mr. Crot∣chet's hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: How your wits gallop!

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Impossible, I never will believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: What a confounded blab you are!

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Oh! I must have burst if I had not told it to Lindamira; besides I knew it would make her happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: There you are out of your guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Theod.
SP.P: Law, Lindy! what's the matter with you? you don't seem to rejoice with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: The scene I have been employed upon, which is the catastrophe of my novel, dwells upon my mind; it is tragic in the deepest degree.—The faithless perjur'd lover after all his promises, forsakes the fond believing fair to wed with ugliness and age for sordid gold, and leaves her to expire with grief and disappointment.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Why will you write any thing so out of nature? no ladies die of grief.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P:
And no gentlemen marry for money—this is your doctrine perhaps, but I am afraid examples of both are to be
found, and wiil be found again; but as the happy event is so near at hand, and you are engaged with parchments, I shall take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: You've done it, mother: there is more mischief in that romantic girl's head, and more wit to execute it, than in forty Fulsome's. Come, let us quit this public-room, and go up stairs; I've something to impart to you.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: A Room in Di Grampus's House, SQUIRE ROBERT meeting JACK CROTCHET.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Fire and faggot! brother traveller, what a blaze have you lighted up in this house; there's old Di in such another taking—Zukers, how she does fume! A steam engine is a fool to her. Never trust me if I coud'nt have tugg'd that Fulsome by the ears, for the spiteful pains the thief took to put you out of favour with her: but keep a good heart, my brave fellow; and remember when I have said the word, I have said it: I have given you my hand once, and here it is again: I am your friend,—blow hot, blow cold, I never budge; one and the same for ever, that's my mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack
SP.P: Squire Robert, you are a man after my own heart. I were a dog if I could look you in the face after this kindness, had I not proof positive in my pocket that I struck no bargain with your aunt till she had settled her whole fortune upon you by the same article that she bound herself to marry me. There's a penalty of ten thousand pounds if she does not fulfil conditions; but if she flouts e because I am Jack Crotchet the printer's son, damme if I wou'd not be set in the pillory as my father was before me, rather than be tied up for life to a hyaena like her.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Why that's honest—have you got it down in black and white?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Sign'd, seal'd, and witness'd—ecce signum! but here, you must take this bond.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: I take it! What must I do with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Hold it safe, hard and fast; let nobody have it out of your hands; 'tis your own security: when I call for you to produce it, have it ready—that's all you have to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Never fear me—safe bind, safe find. There it is.— [puts it up] —Hollo! Stand fast—here comes the in∣former.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Hah! my friend Fulsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Hold there, I'm no friend of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Yes, you are, and the best of friends. How kind is this visit: I am heartily glad to see you; pray be seated.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Vain, idle, thoughtless man, you are doing the honors of a house, that you will not be suffered to remain in five minutes longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: You are merry, always merry and facetious: no man's company more acceptable than Mr. Fulsome's—fine address, ready genius, quick invention—only apt to enlarge a little in the recommendation of his friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: I am very sorry that ever I did enlarge in your re∣commendation, Sir; but I have taken shame to myself, and put Mrs. Diana in possession of your real character.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I am glad of it, for then you disclos'd your own; all the world must applaud you for that amiable zeal, which never boggles at a good-natured lie, when it is to serve a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: A lie do you call it, Sir; a lie?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I beg your pardon—a transgresson of the truth; a slip of memory; a trick of the traveller. Squire, let me present you to Mr. Fulsome, an author of high renown; this is the worthy gentleman, who told your aunt I was descended from an antient noble family, educated at the University, and deeply read in Greek and Latin: when all the world knows I am the son of a pillory printer, educated no where, and having learnt nothing:—if this gentleman is not a liar, who the deuce is?

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: If you call me a liar, Sir, I shall treat you worse than your Captain did.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Captain Waterland was in the right, and I beg'd his pardon; now you are in the wrong, and I'm your man whenever you can find spirit enough to call upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: That's well said, and I'm your second.—So, now, Mr. Informer, name your weapons.

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Weapons, Sir, weapons? I, I,—I don't fight duels—I accept no challenges; my pen is my weapon, and with that I know how to defend myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: And stab your friend behind his back—that's your way of fighting, is it? then I have a great mind, sirrah, you shall have a taste of my way of fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Let him alone; put him peaceably out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Here, Joe!

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Your honor!

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Turn this poltroon peaceably out of the house, and break his neck quietly down the stairs—The fellow's an informer.

SP.SPEAKER: Joe.
SP.P: Oh, the villain! Get along, you ugly toad; be∣gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Ful.
SP.P: Keep the peace! You shall hear of this be assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Dammee! I'll have one kick before he goes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Lindamira as I live—Now we shall have heroic passion in prose run mad.
SP.STAGE: [Sits down to a table, and takes up a newspaper.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Have I found you, base, perfidious monster? Tremble, wretch, at the effects of my revenge, and learn too late how dreadful to awake the rage of her, who lov'd and was betray'd. Do you not hear me? Do you not re∣gard me? What is this feign'd insensibility? Cool, deli∣berate villain, quit this nonsense, and attend to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Come, come, Lindamira, give me the paper; I was in the midst of a very interesting paragraph.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: I'll give you news, if that is what you thirst for, news to strike you dumb—you are ruin'd, and by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: How so, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: I've blasted all your hopes, drawn you in shades black as your own perfidy, and held the horrid likeness up before the eyes of your astonisht bride, that wou'd have been, but never will be now.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Oh! you've been with the lady up stairs, have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: I have, and glory in a just revenge; I have in∣spir'd her bosom with the rage that boils in mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: You have done admirably well for me, but very ill for yourself, Lindamira. If the angry dame declares off, she pays the penalty, and I have ten thousand pounds in my pocket to marry as I like.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: How! what? She forfeits ten thousand pounds if she does not marry you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Exactly so, and you have put her in the very hu∣mour to pay the bond.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: How then is that ill for myself if you are set free?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Because, my darling, I shou'd have laid it and your admirer at your lovely feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: And what shou'd hinder you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: My conscience: Taking your word for truth, that I am a base perfidious monster, a cool deliberate vil∣lain, I really have not the face to approach so pure a be∣ing as you; your virtues awe me: I'll retire to some se∣questered cell, there practice fasting and repentance, and every morning for a penance read my Lindamira's novel, till by frequent meditation on your beautiful descriptions, I fall in love with purling streams and flowery meads, and think no more of love and women.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Did you not deceive me, cruel man? Did you not use me basely? Answer that!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P:
We were poor, Lindamira: You had only a no∣vel for your fortune, and I nothing but my good spirits to support me: you wou'd not trust to my honor, but catch∣ing at the very first word blabb'd out by a silly gossip, started forth on your high horse of heroics, and meant to crush me at once in the true tragedy stile of blank verse
and revenge.—There's your answer, Lindamira; now, if you talk till to-morrow, I won't utter a syllable more.

SP.SPEAKER: Linda.
SP.P: Wretched, wretched Lindamira! undone by my own rash romantic folly. Oh! what had I to do with re∣venge? Detested passion, live only in a novel hencefor∣ward amongst the wealthy and the great, thou art not fit for common life, and common folks like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Your humble servant, learned Sir, your very humble servant!—I found a certain printer in an obscure dirty lane, who writes John Crotchet on his shop-board, and boasts himself to be your honor'd father: I ask'd to be favor'd with a sight of his illustrious pedigree from the antient Saxons of the heptarchy, but he declar'd it was not in his power to furnish me with any lights into the records of his family farther than as he verily believ'd he had a father and mother, but even that, he said, was mat∣ter of faith, and not of certainty.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Sir Toby Grampus, we that cannot count up our generations have oftentimes the sense to outwit you, whose ancestors hang by the wall from Hildebrand, the great Grampus in King Arthur's day, down to little Toby the sprat, in good King George's, God bless him! One of your forefathers perhaps cou'd eat a whole venison pasty for his breakfast; another cou'd bend a kitchen-poker across his arm, a third might keep hawks and greyhounds; what are they but a catalogue of insignificants? One printer, one compositor, one poor corrector of the press, is worth them all, and his country gains more credit by his labors.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: 'Fore George, my friend, I'm not sure but you are in the right of it; I know little of my forefathers, but that that they liv'd on the same spot for many generations, and left me a fair estate to follow the same practice—Sir, I begin to perceive you are a very clever fellow, and if sister Di is of the same opinion, I believe a little printer's ink mixt with our blood wou'd do the family no harm.
SP.STAGE: As JACK is going out DIANA enters.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Stop, Sir, a word with you if you please! whi∣ther are you going so dress'd out?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: To pass an hour at Ranelagh, to beat the round in search of some kind humble girl, who will consent to take up with a printer's son, that has ten thousand pounds in his pocket, and an honest heart in his bosom. I find I am sentenc'd to dismission from your favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Who tells you so?—Hang the fellow how agreeable he is!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Those who told you how little I deserve you—Fulsome and Lindamira.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Can you refute their evidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I shan't attempt it; I rather think they have not told you half my faults and failings.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: That's sincere, however.—He is really a fine figure.—Knowing yourself thus undeserving, as you say you are, why did you strive to make me like you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Because I lik'd you, I hope that's a natural reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Humph! there's a strange mixture in your cha∣racter, my friend, of good and bad, honesty and deceit, rea∣son and rhodomontade.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, I am an odd unsettled fellow, made up of contraries, and 'tis a mere chance which way the tide turns me: good sense and good humour in a wife wou'd guide me to happiness, a fool or a shrew wou'd ship∣wreck me and herself.—And now, Madam, with your per∣mission I will take my leave; having pleaded guilty, I an∣ticipate your sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Stop, Sir, perhaps my heart is not so hard as you suppose; you said you lik'd me once; is your mind alter'd since?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I do not like your listening to informers: I can∣not parry stabs behind my back. I ought to have been present.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Be present then! put off your jaunt to Rane∣lagh; I'll call my friends together, and you shall then be heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Agreed! till then farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Well, go your ways, you are a dear, false, fas∣cinating rogue, and I know not what to do with you or without you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Well, if ever I met with such a man in my life! Lady Jane, I'll be judged by you if I ought to believe one single word that he says, or rather that he swears for he does nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Give him a short answer and send him away if he's troublesome.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: And so I will; what business has he to be talk∣ing to me about love? I never gave him any encourage∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: To be sure you did not. Your behaviour to him at the play, your letter about him to me, your treat∣ment of him at your aunt's, all were clear proofs what you thought of him; but some men, and he is one, never will take an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Oh thou sweet enchanting lovely creature! every sense is lost in rapture while I gaze upon thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: There now he has lost his senses—do hold your tongue; I wont be talk'd to in this way; I protest I'll tell my aunt of you. Do you think I'll have any thing to say to a fencing master? I declare Lady Jane I'm in the humour to take your advice and give him his answer once for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: By all means, Loetitia; a quick riddance of a troublesome companion is the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Then I will do it—but first tell me, Sir, how long in honor and conscience, you expect to live after I have given you a preremptory refusal—Now mind what he'll say.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Not an hour, not a moment: it would be death upon the instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P:
Look you there, now he's going to die, and fix the murder upon me; but I'll not have his life to answer for:—I'll not rob his friends of what they value, his country of
what defends it, the world of what it admires, no, nor my own heart of what it loves and esteems—so there's my hand!—Now, dear Lady Jane, hold him down and don't let him be romping and rioting about in this boisterous manner, for I wont bear it.—Look, look, he's coming on.—Help, help—I'll raise the family—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: There, there! I shall have a scandal brought upon my house.—
Oh! these lovers, these lovers; Mr. Waterland, what shall we do with them?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Copy their example, if I dare tell you what I wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Fie upon you! do you hear him, Laetitia? They are both in a league against us, and we good natur'd simple souls have thrown away our game by playing into their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: We are too good to them by half; kindness does but spoil them. Oh! that I had studied the dear art of tormenting in good time.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Upon my life, George, these ladies do not do us justice, threat'ning us with the torture, when we have both behaved to admiration: Considering how much they have bless'd us, we ought at this moment to be grate∣fully out of our senses.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: For my part I disclaim all responsibility, for I move but as the mistress of my soul directs; in her hand are all those springs, that give it joy or sorrow, health or sickness, life or death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Well, my dear Laetitia, I know not what else we can do but make a common cause and hold lovingly together as friends and sisters should.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: As sisters, lovely Laetitia—do you mark that?

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P:
Certainly; I mark nothing else: The honor of calling Lady Jane my sister will be a consolation under all my sufferings. But first let me have a specimen of your dutiful behaviour to your aunt Di—I take upon me to in∣vite
this good company into counsel upon the grand matter in immediate debate.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What is the question?

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: To wed, or not to wed,—that is the question—lose no time; for, as I take it, we are all just now in the cue to vote for the affirmitive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Delicious! aunt Di struck by the arrows of blind Cupid, and our Box-lobby friend the happy man.—

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: Even so—

P.Q: The happy bridegroom he, and she the blooming bride.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But shall we be welcome after all?

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: I'll engage for that.—Let us set off, we shall just fill the coach.

Was ever woman so perplex'd, distracted and distrest? I cannot state a reason for rejecting this young man, but one starts up to reconcile me to him: no sooner do I lean to mercy, but my pride cries out for vengeance; if love pleads to marry him, prudence whispers me to let it alone: well, well, but what signifies her whisper, when love has all the talk to himself? I'll fairly put the pro's and con's for the last time, and let the strongest carry it.—He's a beggar: granted; that I knew from the first:—he's a low-born tellow, that I did not know, and that's a staggering circumstance—but who's to find it out? He's airy, gay, genteel, well-drest: what has the world to do with pedigrees?—He's ignorant, unlearn'd, uneducated—be it so! He's not pedantic, therefore not conceited, crabbed, a mere book-worm; won't dispute authorities with me, nor wrangle in theology and metaphysics, where the walk will be my own. He is, he is—hush, in short he is here, and all objections vanish.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Most perfect of your sex—your criminal presents himself for judgement; try me with candour, but decide with justice. I pray call your Counsel into Court.
SP.STAGE: Enter GEORGE WATERLAND, Capt. WATERLAND, Lady JANE DANVERS, Sir TOBY GRAMPUS, 'SQUIRE ROBERT, and LAETITIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P:
Brother and nephew, and you, my dear Laeti∣tia,
and this your kind and noble friend, are welcome; these gentlemen also, your second selves, are welcome: they I know are parties, that can judge in cases of the heart; they are also honorable men, to whom I need not blush to make my weakness known, for I confess it is a weakness that has brought me into this dilemma, and con∣strained me to appeal to you my friends for counsel and ad∣vice.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Madam, we come with honest hearts to serve you; not with base design to expose and publish what we hear; we hold for sacred all that you confide to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Here is my pledge, and of your own be∣stowing; I were a wretch too base to breathe, cou'd I betray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: And here am I, your nephew, more beholden to you than all; but when I see this man alone without a friend, I'll risque your anger, and turn over to the weakest side. Now come on as soon as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: By heavens! a noble fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: Bob, Bob! are you wise?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: No, father, but I'm honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Now, Sir, be pleased to answer to a few plain questions:—you came into this familv recommended to me as a gentleman every way qualified to direct the education of my nephew: I receiv'd you, approv'd of you, was pleased with you; your manners, your appearance, your address engag'd me; my partiality for you went great lengths; regarding you as the descendant of a noble family, I pitied you, nay more, with blushes I confess I lov'd you. Are you the well-born gentleman, that I was taught to believe you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: That's an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Are you the man of literature—the scholar?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Nothing less.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: So far, so good.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: What sort of education had you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: None: you took that on the word of Fulsome; let him appear and answer for himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: He'll hardly do that; I kick'd him out of the house this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Bravo! little Monmouthshire, I adore your pirit

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: You are the son of a printer.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I am; many respectable men are of that calling; I don't say my father is one of them, but such as he is, he shall appear: come in, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: Your name is Crotchet.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: John Crotchet is my name, and this is my son; if you have any commands in my way, I shall be proud to serve you: I believe that gentleman was in my shop this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: I was so; I purchas'd two books of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: Fulsome's Travels; I believe you never had more lies for your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: We'll proceed, if you please—Did you not promise marriage to a certain girl nam'd Lindamira?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: She told you so; I have been in search of her, but cannot find her.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: I don't know how you shou'd; for she has run off with that scoundrel Fulsome, both in my debt: It is not a first time I have suffer'd by that fellow: It is a printer's honour not to give up his principal, the rascal was the author of a libel, for which I stood the pelting.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Oh that I had known it! I wou'd have given him t'other kick for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: Now, madam, you have pretty nearly the sum total of my crimes: If every man was sifted so minutely, few wou'd escape ucensur'd. You favor'd me with your re∣gards, and unsolicited proposed to marry me on terms, that my conscience, bad as you may think me, revolted from: I stipulated for your rigutful heir your nephew, accepting for myself a small anuiy.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: A very noble action let me tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I influenc'd you to give your niece the freedom of her choice; you generously complied; a worthy gentleman has cause to bless you for the deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: Oh Heavens! I must embrace this man.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P:
I suffer'd you to force a bond upon me, by which you guarantee'd your marriage on the penalty of ten thou∣sand pounds. I did not think you likely to incur the for∣feiture, and therefore disregarded the amount: Now, Ma∣dam, though I am not worth a doit, I have a spirit, that
disdains to punish any lady, who repents of having lik'd me.—Your nephew has the bond—I never shall enforce it.

SP.SPEAKER: Crotch.
SP.P: The fellow's a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Here, here it is, aunt Di. Now who says Jack Crotchet is not a noble fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: This act indeed is noble.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I must be known to him—Sir, give me leave to take you by the hand. Whilst I am living, you shall never want a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Wat.
SP.P: You are the author of my happiness, my benefactor.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: I hope that Lady can forgive my rudeness at the play.

SP.SPEAKER: Loet.
SP.P: I bless the hour we met.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: Madam, there is but one voice amongst us, and that to give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Toby.
SP.P: She'll marry him, I know she'll marry him. Come, come, a general reconciliation.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Aye, aye, you're all come over to my side at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Diana.
SP.P: I am convinc'd.—And now, if these fair brides will join their lovers hands as cordially as I do mine, Hymen will never welcome a more happy groupe.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: They'll do't, they'll do't! huzza! we are all in the way to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Jane.
SP.P: With heart and hand I join.

SP.SPEAKER: Laet.
SP.P: And I with hand and heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack.
SP.P: And I with both my hands, and all the hearts I have—A heart to honor you, a heart to serve you, and a heart to love you:—When you're sad I'll make you merry; when you're sick I'll make you well. With all my wordly possessions I endow you; with all my learning I celebrate you; with all my titles I enoble you.—One reserve only I keep to mysell, gratitude for your favours, and zeal to merit the protection of this candid audience

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by GEORGE COLMAN, jun. ESQ.
DIV1.L: IN days of yore, when Knights were cas'd in mail,
Like lobsters in a shell, from head to tail;
When sparring nobles, challeng'd to the lists,
Deem'd it ignoble e'er to spar with fists;
Stout were their limbs, and sturdy were their blows;
They met, were slain, or else they slew their foes▪
In modern Challenges how heroes dwindle!
In arms thy're nothing—and in legs they're spindle!
And, ah! how shocking to a Peer of old
Some pugilistic Noble to behold!
Who, when one brute his brother brute opposes,
Stands umpire of black eyes and bloody noses!
How wou'd the Champions, clad in iron suits,
Stare at our Champions, in round hats and boots!
Stare, to see Jacky give his card to Bobby,
And 'Prentice challenge 'Prentice in the Lobby.
That such things are we witness ev'ry day,
When heroes quit the counter for the Play.
When Green-box Errants hurl the sharp retort,
Eager for same, and hot with Beaufoy's port!
"Who are you, Sir?"—"Who am I?—why I'm—Phoo!"
"The world knows me, Sir,—damme, who are you?
"Meet me to-morrow morning, in Hyde Park"—
"I'm Mr. Plumb, the Banker's, fifteenth Clerk."—
Oh! may these warriors of the Desk and Quill
Pursue their petty broils and Challenge still;
Of such contentions wholesome be the fruit!
And Duelling be brought to disrepute;
May Englishman no Englishman oppose,
But wield his sword against our common foes!
